item.content:encoded:
Have you been bother about the complex UI in Word when you just want to write some notes? Have you wondered whether there is a way to simply type maths expression? If you have the same complain as me, markdown would be the best solution.

Reasons for using Markdown

  • easy to use
  • easy to integrate with Tex/Latex and other utilities
  • easy to export into other format (e.g. pdf, html, docx, rtf)
  • lightweight
  • code highlighting
  • universal access (most editors are cross-platform)

(some features are not supported by all editors)

üåà Get start with markdown

First of all, you need an editor to start with. Personally, I recommend to use Typora but you can also find tons of other app which has similar functionality. Just click the link or go to https://www.typora.io/. Scroll to bottom and there choose the version for your OS. In this article, I will use MacOS version to demonstrate.

The start screen of Typora is minimalism with only the essential info.

You can quick edit the file location and name by clicking the file name, and see stats on the right top of the window. More settings can be found in the menu bar.

OK, so now I‚Äôve set up the editor, but what is markdown? ü§î

Markdown is originally created by Daring Fireball.

Wikipedia would tell you that

Markdown is a lightweight markup language with plain text formatting syntax. Its design allows it to be converted to many output formats, but the original tool by the same name only supports HTML Markdown is often used to format readme files, for writing messages in online discussion forums, and to create rich text using a plain text editor.

Let me show you what this means.

Markdown file markups text which can be recognised by editors or phasers. For example, different levels of header are recognised by the number of #, one # indicates level one header. You can definitely add effects on text using code, but I prefer to use keyboard shortcuts. On macOS, ‚åò 1 change the current line into a level one header. And you can change the header level by ‚åò - and ‚åò =.

List of a few shortcuts for Typora on macOS

You can find a full list of shortcuts in the [here](http://support.typora.io/Shortcut-Keys/).

How to embed Maths expression

Typora provides two ways for embedding maths expressions. Inline maths and maths block.

Inline maths $‚Ä¶$

With inline maths, you can embed a maths expression e.g. y=‚à´x2‚Äâdxy=\int x^2 \,dxy=‚à´x2dx in text line.

Inline maths can be implied by using $‚Ä¶$, where ‚Ä¶ represents Latex command. For example, the source code of the above line is

With inline maths, you can embed a maths expression e.g. $y=\int x^2 \,dx$ in text line.

You need to enable this feature first as it‚Äôs disabled in default in the preference Panel / Markdown Tab.

Maths block $$‚Ä¶$$

Maths block allows you to display maths expression in individual space.

f(x)=‚à´‚àí‚àû‚àûf^Œæ‚Äâe2œÄiŒæx‚ÄâdŒæf(x) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty \hat f\xi\,e^{2 \pi i \xi x} \,d\xif(x)=‚à´‚àí‚àû‚àû‚Äãf^‚ÄãŒæe2œÄiŒæxdŒæ

Maths block can be implied by using $$‚Ä¶$$, where ‚Ä¶ represents Latex command. For example, the source code of the above line is

$$
f(x) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty
    \hat f\xi\,e^{2 \pi i \xi x}
    \,d\xi
$$

Typora uses MathJax to render maths expression, a full list of supported Tex/Latex command can be found here.

Let‚Äôs talk about Code Highlighting üë®‚Äçüíªüë©‚Äçüíª

If you don‚Äôt have the habit of taking notes on what you code, I strongly recommend you to do so. It‚Äôs very helpful when you go back to code you typed weeks ago if you have an outline of them. Markdown is the right tool to do this job.

#include <iostream>
using namespace std;
int main(){
  cout << "Hello world!" << endl;
  return 0;
}

Markdown uses the syntax ```‚Ä¶``` to start a code block or `‚Ä¶` to embed an inline code snippet.

Example of Code Block

‚Äã```javascript
function double(x){
	let y = 2*x;
	return y;
}
‚Äã```
Remark

When using code block, you can specify the language of code.

Example of Inline Code

If you want to use `stoi`, you need to add `#include <string>` to the head of file.

Other syntaxes ‚å®Ô∏è

Task list - [ ]

  • Wait to be finished
  • Finished
- [ ] Wait to be finished
- [x] Finished

Links [ ]( )

link to this blog

[link to this blog](http://blog.charleswang.name/markdown)

Unordered Lists -

  • element
  • element
- element
- element

Ordered Lists num.

  1. First element
  2. Second element
1. First element
2. Second element
Remark

A full list of syntax supported by Typora can be found here.

Conclusion üö©

I‚Äôve given a few examples of what you can do with markdown. It‚Äôs time back to the question, why markdown. Surely, we have apps like OneNote that support handwriting and Pages/Word that has advanced support for tables and charts. Markdown is not an ultimate solution for text editing, it exists more likes a simple and reliable tool that you can rely on when you want to write. You can open and edit a markdown even in the CUI, that‚Äôs why developers use markdown to write README.

Bonus

Typora supports some common html syntax. For example,

<span style='color: orange; font-size: 30px;'>These words are decorated using html and css. </span>

The code above is written in html, the text between <span> and </span> is content and the text quoted after style specifies style of content. It would be rendered as below.

These words are decorated using html and css. 

<iframe class="airtable-embed" src="https://airtable.com/embed/shrwreRAwStgGX8NA?backgroundColor=blue&layout=card" frameborder="0" onmousewheel="" width="100%" height="200" style="background: transparent; border: 1px solid #ccc;"></iframe>

Remember the table I used to show keyboard shortcut? It is embedded as iframe block in markdown. And, yes, this blog is written in markdown.

item.title: Run Ubuntu on Mac via Docker
item.description: To ensure consistance across platforms, we were suggested to install ubuntu as vertual system in our first lecture on Programming. Dr David‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
To ensure consistance across platforms, we were suggested to install ubuntu as vertual system in our first lecture on Programming. Dr David Thomas provides us with detailed solutions to get ubuntu on MacOS and Windows by VirtualBox and Hyper-V. But due to unknown reasons(probably lack of adaption to this latest OS version), VirtualBox often crashes on latest macOS Catalina. Here is an alternate way to run ubuntu on macOS.

  • You will be able to have a folder called ‚Äúubuntu‚Äù on your desktop which linked to /src/ in ubuntu.
  • You will be able to start ubuntu in about 1 second.
  • Docker container takes less resources on your computer than vm.
  • BUT no graphic user interface.

1. Download Docker (1.5 min)

Copy and paste the following link to the address bar of your preferred bowser would start the download of Docker-Desktop for Mac.

2. Install Docker (1 min)

  • Drag and drop Docker into Application folder. And wait for the process to complete.

  • When completed, you should be able to see Docker in your launchpad.

3. Start Docker (0.5 min)

  • Click Docker in the launchpad to start it. You should then be able to see Docker icon in the status bar.

  • Sign up and login into a docker account is not necessary. Just wait util it shows ‚ÄúDocker Desktop is running‚Äù.

Get Ubuntu run (1 min)

  • Open Spotlight Search ‚åò + SPACE and type ‚Äúterminal‚Äù in the pop-up window.

  • Open Terminal.

  • Copy and paste the following code. Press Enter to run.

mkdir /Users/$USER/Desktop/ubuntu;
docker run \
  ‚Äîname ubuntu \
  -e HOST_IP=$(ifconfig en0 | awk '/ *inet /{print $2}') \
  -v /Users/$USER/Desktop/ubuntu:/src \
  -t -I \
  ubuntu /bin/bash

  • If you see something like this, Ubuntu is already up and running.

  • You are now in the ubuntu. Check by run cat /etc/lsb-release

Install dependency and tools (0.5 min)

Continue in the previous window, run the following code one by one.

apt-get update
apt-get upgrade
apt-get install nano g++

Congratulations

Next time when you want to use ubuntu, just open terminal and run

docker start ubuntu; docker exec -it ubuntu /bin/bash

Make sure Docker is running before run the code.

P.S. You can create a new profile in terminal that run this code at start to save time.
